results.title: Language at twelve (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Andrew Frazer, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch Your Language”.
Intended primarily to emphasise the diversity and complexity of language in the life of a 12-year-old. This film focuses on two 12-year-olds who are involved in a school language project. Shows their interaction with a sufficient number of significant people in their lives for us to gain an impression of how the demands upon their speech shift. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Karl McPhee, Andrew Frazer, Tom Manefield and Film Australia

results.title: Tales from a suitcase 3
results.creator_credit: Andrea Dal Bosco, David S. Vadiveloo, Will Davies, Look Television Productions and SBS Independent
results.brief_description: This acclaimed SBS series presents the stories behind migration to Australia during the 1950s when many people fled post-War atrocities, the rise of Communism and impoverishment. This tape contains three separate stories. Episode 7: Jutta Malnic, born in Berlin to an Australian mother and German father, had a childhood filled with exotic stories about a country which provided refuge after harrowing World War II experiences. A photographer, Jutta relays her remarkable journey from war-torn Europe and her interesting experiences as an emigre. Episode 8: Victor Vadiveloo was taken from his family in Sri Lanka at age 4 and sent to work on the Burmese railway at 14, before escaping. Upon emigrating to Australia Victor continued his studies in order to become a surgeon, and experienced excessive racism which only intensified when he fell in love and married a white woman. Episode 9: Rinaldo Fabbro, an Italian partisan fighter during World War II who was to become an architect of great acclaim, discusses his past, having arrived in Australia in 1949, in search of prosperity. Some quite remarkable tales emerge about these interesting times, told with finesse by various raconteurs and are an appealing mix of pathos and humour.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrea Dal Bosco, David S. Vadiveloo, Will Davies, Look Television Productions and SBS Independent

results.title: Take a ride
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Don Murray, Commonwealth Department of Transport and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Because of increased traffic congestion, State Governments are taking new initiatives in transport planning, especially in the area of public transport. Looks at the different transport systems in each state, and improvements planned.

results.title: Talking heads by Alan Bennett
results.creator_credit: Alan Bennett, Giles Foster, Stuart Burge, Tristram Powell, Innes Lloyd and BBC
results.brief_description: Six monologues (each approx. 36 mins.) written by Alan Bennett and delivered by five of Britain’s most auspicious female actors (Patricia Routledge, Maggie Smith, Julie Walters, Thora Hird, Stephanie Cole) and Bennett himself. Made for television and originally screened in Britain in 1987, each piece displays the wry observations, knowing irony and tender understatement that are characteristic of Bennett’s writing style. The suburban normality of the world his characters inhabit belies their lives of secrets, revelations, fears, crimes and passions. They tell their stories, and in doing so reveal more than they know of the humour, passion and sadness of their lives.

results.title: Talking about Belonging
results.creator_credit: Philip Robertson, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Talking about “Belonging” is a follow-up of a three-part series, the first two parts being “Belonging…the first week” and “Belonging…the second week”. The series is a study of social interaction in the town of Wellington, New South Wales. Through the lives of four men, it shows how in country towns there are those who “belong” and those who don’t - women, Aboriginals, the poor, the unemployed. “Talking about Belonging” is a discussion between the four men and their families with the filmmaker Philip Robertson and sociologist Kate Gillen when they first saw the completed film. Shows how the men see themselves. Also explores the creation of a “sense of belonging” in an Australian country town.

results.title: Take a little time: infection control at work
results.creator_credit: Fiona Banks, Hilary Christmas, Film Victoria, Tanglefoot Productions and Victoria. Health Dept. AIDS STD Unit

results.title: Taj Mahal
results.creator_credit: James Ramiessenger and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: A study of the Taj Mahal in Agra. An impression of the interior and exterior of the old mausoleum, and the surrounding gardens; story of Shar Jahan and the erection of Taj Mahal to the memory of his wife; the blending of Saracenic and Hindu styles in the architecture; the inlay work in some precious stones, marble bas-reliefs and the lace-like marble screens around the tombs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: James Ramiessenger and Documentary Films of India

results.title: Talk 16
results.creator_credit: Adrienne Mitchell, Janis Lundman, Back Alley Film Productions and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is a most compelling and entertaining documentary about the personal lives of five young teenage girls aged between 15 and 16. Filmed over a one-year period, Janis Lundman and Adrienne Mitchell formed quite a remarkable bond with the girls, allowing the filmmakers to present an up-close and intimate insight into each of their lives. Meet Lina, Russian born, migrated to Canada with her family when she was 5 years old, inwardly rebellious and striving to be thought of as an adult by her family - her main aim in life is to find a boyfriend; Erin is from a middle-class family, attends private school, and wants to be a model but struggles with problems of body-image; Helen of Korean-born parents who are devout Christians and hold strict family values, is an honors student caught between two cultures; Astra, a runaway teenager, is an enigma - perceptive and articulate who considers herself a problem child, hates living by the rules and enjoys living on the edge, hanging out with druggies and ex-crims; Rhonda, brash, black and ambitious skips classes but will do anything to achieve her ambition to be an actress. From different socio-economic and cultural backgrounds, together these five young girls discuss sex, drugs, boyfriends, their future, feminism, beliefs and values, body image, and family with amazing frankness and humour. An interesting concept to see the changes in each of the girls over the year of filming. Voice and narration by Janis Lundman. (Award: Florida Film Festival 1994, Grand Jury Award)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Adrienne Mitchell, Janis Lundman, Back Alley Film Productions and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Tales of the city [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Alan Poul, Antony Root, Alastair Reid, Channel 4, Propaganda and Working Title Films
results.brief_description: Since beginning as a serial,”Tales of the City”, in the San Francisco Chronicle, Armistead Maupin’s charming and very funny books about a group of people living in a block of flats in ‘70’s San Francisco has entertained people worldwide. This joint UK/USA production follows the story of Mary Ann Singleton, a young girl from the mid-west who moves into a flat owned by the wonderful Mrs Madrigal (Olympia Dukakis), a landlady who always has a willing shoulder to cry on and an endless supply of joints. Mary Ann becomes best friends with the handsome Mouse, a young man looking for Mr. Right. In this mad, exuberant world of disco, fast sex and good drugs, we follow the adventures of Mouse, Mary Ann and their fellow tenants as they fall in and out of love, party, and pick up strangers in laundromats. This excellent series is a glorious, comic tribute to a time when hedonism was innocent and when sex was safe. Co-starring Chloe Webb, Donald Moffat and Laura Linney. Screenplay by Richard Kramer.
